title: 107_hr2523
content: The Act is known as the "Federal Employees' Benefits Equity Act of 2001" and pertains to the civil service retirement system. Section 8339 of title 5, United States Code is amended to include provisions for retirement benefits for law enforcement officers, firefighters, nuclear materials couriers, and Supreme Court Police after 20 years of service. In subsection (e), paragraph (2) allows air traffic controllers retiring after 20 years of service to have their annuity computed under specific conditions. In subsection (q), paragraph (2) applies to Capitol Police or law enforcement officers retiring after 20 years of service. Section 8341(d) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include specific conditions for computing the annuity of Capitol Police or law enforcement officers retiring after 20 years of service. Section 8342 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for employees with service as law enforcement officers, firefighters, nuclear materials couriers, or Capitol Police/Surpreme Court Police, who had retirement deductions withheld at a higher rate. The amendment to Section 8342 of title 5, United States Code, includes provisions for annuities for survivors of deceased employees, particularly those who were members of the Capitol Police, with specific conditions for eligibility. The difference in employee deductions for service as a Capitol Police member at a higher rate, compared to the rate applicable to all employees, along with interest, will be paid to the annuitant or beneficiary of a deceased employee. The federal employees' retirement system includes deductions for service as a Capitol Police member at a higher rate, with interest paid to the annuitant or beneficiary of a deceased employee. The federal employees' retirement system includes amendments to annuity calculations for law enforcement officers, firefighters, Capitol Police, Supreme Court Police, nuclear materials couriers, and air traffic controllers. An employee's annuity is based on their average pay and total years of service, with specific percentages allocated for different categories of service. The retirement system for federal employees includes amendments to annuity calculations for various service categories such as law enforcement officers, firefighters, Capitol Police, Supreme Court Police, air traffic controllers, and nuclear materials couriers. An employee's annuity is based on their average pay and total years of service, with specific percentages allocated for different categories of service. The retirement system for federal employees includes amendments to annuity calculations for different service categories like law enforcement officers, firefighters, Capitol Police, Supreme Court Police, air traffic controllers, and nuclear materials couriers. An employee's annuity is based on their average pay and total years of service, with specific percentages allocated for different categories of service. An annuity may not be computed under certain sections for Capitol Police members or survivors entitled to annuities based on specific criteria. The retirement system for federal employees includes amendments to annuity calculations for different service categories like law enforcement officers, firefighters, Capitol Police, Supreme Court Police, air traffic controllers, and nuclear materials couriers. An annuitant not based on an annuity computed under specific sections, including service as a member of the Capitol Police, shall receive the difference in employee deductions at a higher percentage rate with interest, as prescribed by the Office. Section 8442 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include specific references for annuity calculations. The retirement system for federal employees includes amendments to annuity calculations for different service categories. Section 8415(b)-(d) and (g) apply to employees or Members who meet age and service requirements at the date of death. Subsection (c)(2)(A)(i) is amended to reference section 8415 without subsection (d). The amendments made by this Act will be effective on the date of enactment and will only apply to individuals who separate from employment subject to specific chapters of title 5, United States Code, on or after the enactment date.
